1→# CLAUDE.md
     2→
     3→Always use Context7 MCP when I need library/API documentation, code generation, setup or configuration steps without me having to explicitly ask.
     4→
     5→# Project
     6→
     7→Linkblog Service - a personal bookmarking API (NestJS + TypeScript + Supabase) that publishes an RSS feed for luther.io/blogroll.
     8→
     9→See `docs/implementation-plan.md` for the full implementation plan and architecture.
    10→
    11→## Key Conventions
    12→
    13→- **Endpoints:** `/links` (CRUD, API key protected), `/feed` (public RSS 2.0), `/health` (public)
    14→- **Auth:** Single-user, no auth system. Write endpoints use `x-api-key` header checked against `API_KEY` env var.
    15→- **Data model:** `links` table in Supabase (id, url, title, summary, created_at, updated_at)
    16→- **Deploy:** AWS App Runner via Docker
    17→
    18→## Environment Variables
    19→
    20→- `SUPABASE_URL` - Supabase project URL
    21→- `SUPABASE_ANON_KEY` - Supabase anonymous key
    22→- `API_KEY` - Protects write endpoints via `x-api-key` header
    23→- `PORT` - Server port (set by App Runner in production)
    24→
    25→## Supabase JS Client (`@supabase/supabase-js`)
    26→
    27→- **Version:** v2.x (latest)
    28→- **Init:** `createClient<Database>(SUPABASE_URL, SUPABASE_ANON_KEY, options)` — use generated types for full type safety
    29→- **Type generation:** `npx supabase gen types typescript --project-id <ref> > database.types.ts`
    30→- **Server-side options:** Disable auth features not needed in a backend service:
    31→  ```ts
    32→  createClient<Database>(url, key, {
    33→    auth: { autoRefreshToken: false, persistSession: false },
    34→  })
    35→  ```
    36→- **Query patterns (all return `{ data, error }`):**
    37→  - Select: `supabase.from('links').select('*').order('created_at', { ascending: false })`
    38→  - Select one: `supabase.from('links').select('*').eq('id', id).single()`
    39→  - Insert: `supabase.from('links').insert({ url, title, summary }).select()`
    40→  - Update: `supabase.from('links').update({ title, updated_at: new Date().toISOString() }).eq('id', id).select()`
    41→  - Delete: `supabase.from('links').delete().eq('id', id)`
    42→  - Upsert: `supabase.from('links').upsert(row, { onConflict: 'id' }).select()`
    43→  - Count: `supabase.from('links').select('*', { count: 'exact', head: false })`
    44→- **Filters:** `.eq()`, `.neq()`, `.gt()`, `.gte()`, `.lt()`, `.lte()`, `.like()`, `.ilike()`, `.in()`
    45→- **Pagination:** `.order(column, { ascending })`, `.limit(n)`, `.range(from, to)`
    46→- **Error handling:** Always check `error` before using `data` — errors are returned, not thrown
    47→
    48→## Workflow
    49→
    50→- All code changes must reference a GitHub issue. Check `gh issue list` before starting work.
    51→- Use `oxlint` for linting and formatting.
    52→
    53→## Testing (Postman)
    54→
    55→- `postman/collection.json` — API collection (folders: Health, Links, Feed, CRUD Workflow)
    56→- `postman/environment.json` — "Linkblog - Local" env (vars: `baseUrl`, `apiKey`, `linkId`)
    57→- `postman/specs/` — reserved for API specs
    58→- Auth edge case tests (no key, wrong key) live in the Health folder, not a separate folder
    59→- Links and CRUD Workflow folders use folder-level `x-api-key` auth via `{{apiKey}}`
    60→- Test scripts auto-capture `linkId` from create/list responses for downstream requests
    61→
    62→## Gotchas
    63→
    64→- `but commit` uses `-p <cli-id>` (or `--changes`) to commit specific files, not `--files` or `-F`.
    65→- GitHub repo: `vidluther/linkblog` - use with `gh` commands.
    66→
    67→# Skills
    68→
    69→Use the gitbutler skill to handle version control.
    70→Use the github-issues-first skill before implementing any code changes.
    71→

content.content:
1→---
     2→layout: default
     3→title: Implementation Plan
     4→---
     5→
     6→# Linkblog Service - Implementation Plan
     7→
     8→## Overview
     9→
    10→A personal bookmarking API built with NestJS + TypeScript + Supabase. Stores articles with notes and publishes them as a public RSS feed for the blogroll at luther.io/blogroll.
    11→
    12→## Architecture
    13→
    14→```
    15→Client (curl/scripts) --> NestJS API --> Supabase (Postgres)
    16→                              |
    17→                              +--> GET /feed (public RSS 2.0)
    18→                              +--> CRUD /links (API key protected)
    19→```
    20→
    21→### Key Decisions
    22→
    23→- **Single-user, no auth system** - write endpoints protected by API key (`x-api-key` header)
    24→- **API-only** - no frontend, interaction via API calls
    25→- **Minimal data model** - url, title, summary, created_at, updated_at
    26→- **RSS 2.0 feed** - public, reverse chronological, consumed by luther.io at build time
    27→- **Deploy** - AWS App Runner via Docker
    28→
    29→### Data Model
    30→
    31→**Table: `links`**
    32→
    33→| Column     | Type        | Constraints   |
    34→| ---------- | ----------- | ------------- |
    35→| id         | integer     | PK            |
    36→| url        | text        |               |
    37→| title      | text        |               |
    38→| summary    | text        |               |
    39→| created_at | timestamptz | default now() |
    40→| updated_at | timestamptz | default now() |
    41→
    42→### Endpoints
    43→
    44→| Method | Path       | Auth    | Description                         |
    45→| ------ | ---------- | ------- | ----------------------------------- |
    46→| POST   | /links     | API key | Create a link                       |
    47→| GET    | /links     | API key | List all links (desc by created_at) |
    48→| GET    | /links/:id | API key | Get a single link                   |
    49→| PATCH  | /links/:id | API key | Update a link                       |
    50→| DELETE | /links/:id | API key | Delete a link (204)                 |
    51→| GET    | /feed      | Public  | RSS 2.0 feed                        |
    52→| GET    | /health    | Public  | Health check for App Runner         |
    53→
    54→## GitHub Issues
    55→
    56→| Issue | Title                                              | Depends On | Status |
    57→| ----- | -------------------------------------------------- | ---------- | ------ |
    58→| #1    | Initialize Repository with Development Tooling     | —          | Closed |
    59→| #2    | Create implementation plan                          | —          | Closed |
    60→| #3    | Provision Supabase project & create `links` table   | —          | Closed |
    61→| #4    | Set up NestJS project skeleton                      | #1         | Closed |
    62→| #5    | Create Supabase client provider                     | #4         | Closed |
    63→| #6    | Implement links service (CRUD via Supabase)         | #5         | Open   |
    64→| #7    | Implement links controller & API-key guard          | #6         | Open   |
    65→| #8    | Implement RSS Feed endpoint (`/feed`)               | #6         | Open   |
    66→
    67→## Implementation Phases
    68→
    69→### Phase 1: Foundation (Issues #1–#4) ✅
    70→
    71→**Goal:** Project scaffolded, database ready.
    72→
    73→- [x] Initialize repo with development tooling (Issue #1)
    74→- [x] Create implementation plan (Issue #2)
    75→- [x] Provision Supabase project & create `links` table with migration and seed data (Issue #3)
    76→- [x] Set up NestJS project skeleton with TypeScript strict mode, oxlint, links module scaffold (Issue #4)
    77→
    78→### Phase 2: Supabase Client (Issue #5) ✅
    79→
    80→**Goal:** NestJS can talk to Supabase.
    81→
    82→- [x] Install `@nestjs/config` and configure `ConfigModule.forRoot({ isGlobal: true })`
    83→- [x] Create `SupabaseModule` (`@Global()`) that provides a configured `@supabase/supabase-js` client
    84→- [x] Client options disable `autoRefreshToken` and `persistSession` (server-side best practice)
    85→- [x] Import `SupabaseModule` in `AppModule`
    86→- [x] Verify connection works with a simple query
    87→
    88→### Phase 3: Core API (Issues #6, #7)
    89→
    90→**Goal:** Full CRUD for links, protected by API key.
    91→
    92→#### Links Service (Issue #6)
    93→
    94→- [x] `findAll()` — returns links ordered by `created_at` descending
    95→- [ ] `findOne(id)` — returns a single link or throws `NotFoundException`
    96→- [ ] `create(dto)` — inserts a link and returns it
    97→- [ ] `update(id, dto)` — updates and returns, throws if missing
    98→- [ ] `remove(id)` — deletes, throws if missing
    99→- [ ] All methods check `{ data, error }` and throw on error
   100→- [ ] Unit tests with mocked Supabase client
   101→
   102→#### Controller & API Key Guard (Issue #7)
   103→
   104→- [ ] `ApiKeyGuard` reads `x-api-key` header, compares to `API_KEY` env var, returns 401 on mismatch
   105→- [ ] `GET /links` and `GET /links/:id` — public
   106→- [ ] `POST /links`, `PATCH /links/:id`, `DELETE /links/:id` — protected
   107→- [ ] DTOs use `class-validator` decorators
   108→- [ ] E2e tests (with and without valid API key)
   109→
   110→### Phase 4: RSS Feed (Issue #8)
   111→
   112→**Goal:** Public RSS feed for luther.io consumption.
   113→
   114→- [ ] Create `FeedModule` + `FeedController`
   115→- [ ] `GET /feed` returns RSS 2.0 XML (`Content-Type: application/rss+xml`)
   116→- [ ] Uses `feed` npm package to build RSS document
   117→- [ ] Each link → `<item>` with `<title>`, `<link>`, `<description>`, `<pubDate>`, `<guid>`
   118→- [ ] Unit/e2e test verifies valid XML output
   119→
   120→### Phase 5: Deployment (no issue yet)
   121→
   122→**Goal:** Dockerized and deployable to AWS App Runner.
   123→
   124→- [ ] Multi-stage Dockerfile (build + production with slim Node base)
   125→- [ ] `.dockerignore` (node_modules, .git, .env, etc.)
   126→- [ ] `GET /health` endpoint for App Runner health checks
   127→- [ ] PORT read from environment (App Runner sets this)
   128→
   129→## Dependency Graph
   130→
   131→```
   132→Phase 1:  #1 (tooling) ──> #4 (skeleton) ──> #5 (supabase client)
   133→          #2 (plan)                                │
   134→          #3 (schema)                              v
   135→                                              #6 (service) ──┬──> #7 (controller + guard)
   136→                                                             └──> #8 (RSS feed)
   137→```
   138→

1→# Linkblog Service
     2→
     3→This is my personal linkblog app.
     4→
     5→### What is this?
     6→
     7→This is a service that allows me to do the following:
     8→
     9→1. I want to be able to bookmark articles I find interesting with a summary or note of why I found it interesting.
    10→1. I want to be able to look through those bookmarks based on my summary and notes.
    11→1. I want to populate the [blogroll](https://luther.io/blogroll) section of my site with those articles. Because sharing is caring.
    12→
    13→### Why does this exist?
    14→
    15→[Here's my blog post explaining why this exists](https://luther.io/articles/linkblog/)
    16→
    17→### Stack
    18→
    19→My goal is to learn TypeScript, and NestJS along with Supabase. So..
    20→
    21→- TypeScript
    22→- NestJS
    23→- Supabase
    24→

1→---
     2→layout: default
     3→title: Architecture
     4→---
     5→
     6→# Architecture
     7→
     8→## Overview
     9→
    10→Linkblog is a single-purpose API service. There is no frontend — it is designed to be called by scripts, shortcuts, or other services. The public RSS feed is consumed by [luther.io](https://luther.io) at build time.
    11→
    12→```
    13→                           ┌─────────────────────────┐
    14→                           │      Supabase (DB)       │
    15→                           │  ┌───────────────────┐   │
    16→                           │  │   links table      │   │
    17→                           │  │   (Postgres)       │   │
    18→                           │  └───────────────────┘   │
    19→                           └────────────▲─────────────┘
    20→                                        │
    21→                                        │  @supabase/supabase-js
    22→                                        │
    23→┌──────────────┐           ┌────────────┴─────────────┐
    24→│  curl / apps │──────────▶│      NestJS API          │
    25→└──────────────┘   HTTP    │                          │
    26→                           │  POST/GET/PATCH/DELETE    │
    27→                           │  /links    (API key)     │
    28→                           │                          │
    29→                           │  GET /feed  (public RSS) │
    30→                           │  GET /health (public)    │
    31→                           └──────────────────────────┘
    32→                                        │
    33→                                        │  Docker
    34→                                        ▼
    35→                           ┌──────────────────────────┐
    36→                           │    AWS App Runner         │
    37→                           └──────────────────────────┘
    38→```
    39→
    40→## NestJS Module Structure
    41→
    42→```
    43→AppModule
    44→├── ConfigModule          (global, loads .env)
    45→├── SupabaseModule        (global, provides Supabase client)
    46→├── LinksModule           (CRUD service + controller)
    47→└── FeedModule            (RSS feed generation) [planned]
    48→```
    49→
    50→### AppModule
    51→
    52→The root module. Imports `ConfigModule.forRoot({ isGlobal: true })` so environment variables are available everywhere, plus `SupabaseModule` and `LinksModule`.
    53→
    54→### SupabaseModule
    55→
    56→A `@Global()` module that creates and exports a configured `SupabaseClient`. It uses `ConfigService` to read `SUPABASE_URL` and `SUPABASE_ANON_KEY`, and disables `autoRefreshToken` and `persistSession` since this is a server-side app with no browser sessions.
    57→
    58→The client is provided under the `SUPABASE_CLIENT` injection token.
    59→
    60→### LinksModule
    61→
    62→Contains the `LinksService` (business logic and Supabase queries) and `LinksController` (HTTP endpoints). The service injects the `SUPABASE_CLIENT` token and performs all database operations.
    63→
    64→### FeedModule (planned)
    65→
    66→Will contain a `FeedController` that reads links from the database and returns an RSS 2.0 XML document using the `feed` npm package.
    67→
    68→## Key Design Decisions
    69→
    70→### Single-user, API-key auth
    71→
    72→There is no user system. A single `API_KEY` environment variable protects write operations. This keeps the codebase minimal — the only consumer is the project owner.
    73→
    74→### Supabase as the data layer
    75→
    76→Instead of running a Postgres instance, the service uses Supabase's hosted Postgres via the `@supabase/supabase-js` client. This provides:
    77→
    78→- Managed database with automatic backups
    79→- REST-like query API from the JS client
    80→- Migrations managed via the Supabase CLI
    81→- Free tier sufficient for a personal project
    82→
    83→### RSS as the output format
    84→
    85→The primary consumer of link data is [luther.io](https://luther.io), which fetches the RSS feed at build time. RSS 2.0 was chosen because it is universally supported and simple to generate.
    86→
    87→### No frontend
    88→
    89→The API is meant to be called from scripts, iOS shortcuts, or CLI tools. A frontend would add unnecessary complexity for a single-user tool.
    90→
    91→## Request Flow
    92→
    93→1. Client sends HTTP request to NestJS
    94→2. For protected endpoints, the `ApiKeyGuard` checks the `x-api-key` header
    95→3. Controller delegates to `LinksService`
    96→4. `LinksService` calls Supabase via `@supabase/supabase-js`
    97→5. Supabase returns `{ data, error }`
    98→6. Service checks for errors, throws NestJS exceptions if needed
    99→7. Controller returns the response to the client
   100→
   101→## Directory Structure
   102→
   103→```
   104→linkblog/
   105→├── docs/                  # GitHub Pages documentation
   106→├── postman/
   107→│   ├── collection.json    # Postman collection (all endpoints + tests)
   108→│   ├── environment.json   # "Linkblog - Local" environment
   109→│   └── specs/             # API specs (planned)
   110→├── src/
   111→│   ├── main.ts            # Bootstrap and start server
   112→│   ├── app.module.ts      # Root module
   113→│   ├── app.controller.ts  # Health check / root endpoint
   114→│   ├── app.service.ts     # App-level service
   115→│   ├── supabase/
   116→│   │   └── supabase.module.ts   # Supabase client provider
   117→│   └── links/
   118→│       ├── links.module.ts      # Links feature module
   119→│       ├── links.service.ts     # CRUD business logic
   120→│       ├── links.controller.ts  # HTTP endpoints
   121→│       ├── dto/
   122→│       │   ├── create-link.dto.ts
   123→│       │   └── update-link.dto.ts
   124→│       └── entities/
   125→│           └── link.entity.ts
   126→├── supabase/
   127→│   ├── config.toml        # Supabase CLI config
   128→│   ├── migrations/        # SQL migrations
   129→│   └── seed.sql           # Sample data
   130→├── test/                  # E2e tests
   131→├── package.json
   132→├── tsconfig.json
   133→└── CLAUDE.md              # Project conventions
   134→```
   135→
   136→---
   137→
   138→Next: [Deployment](deployment)
   139→

1→---
     2→layout: default
     3→title: API Reference
     4→---
     5→
     6→# API Reference
     7→
     8→Base URL: `http://localhost:3000` (local) or your deployed App Runner URL.
     9→
    10→> **Tip:** A ready-to-use Postman collection is available in `postman/collection.json` with pre-built requests, test scripts, and a CRUD workflow runner. See [Getting Started](getting-started#using-postman) for setup.
    11→
    12→## Authentication
    13→
    14→Write endpoints (`POST`, `PATCH`, `DELETE`) require an API key passed as a request header:
    15→
    16→```
    17→x-api-key: your-api-key
    18→```
    19→
    20→The key is compared against the `API_KEY` environment variable. Requests with a missing or incorrect key receive a `401 Unauthorized` response.
    21→
    22→Read endpoints (`GET /links`, `GET /links/:id`) are also protected by the API key.
    23→
    24→The RSS feed (`GET /feed`) and health check (`GET /health`) are **public**.
    25→
    26→---
    27→
    28→## Endpoints
    29→
    30→### `GET /health`
    31→
    32→Health check for load balancers and uptime monitors.
    33→
    34→**Auth:** None
    35→
    36→```bash
    37→curl http://localhost:3000/health
    38→```
    39→
    40→**Response:** `200 OK`
    41→
    42→---
    43→
    44→### `POST /links`
    45→
    46→Create a new link.
    47→
    48→**Auth:** `x-api-key` header required
    49→
    50→**Request body:**
    51→
    52→```json
    53→{
    54→  "url": "https://example.com/article",
    55→  "title": "Interesting Article",
    56→  "summary": "A short note about why this is worth reading."
    57→}
    58→```
    59→
    60→| Field     | Type   | Required | Description                     |
    61→| --------- | ------ | -------- | ------------------------------- |
    62→| `url`     | string | yes      | The URL being bookmarked        |
    63→| `title`   | string | yes      | Display title for the link      |
    64→| `summary` | string | no       | Your notes or a brief summary   |
    65→
    66→**Example:**
    67→
    68→```bash
    69→curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/links \
    70→  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    71→  -H "x-api-key: your-api-key" \
    72→  -d '{"url":"https://example.com","title":"Example","summary":"A test link"}'
    73→```
    74→
    75→**Response:** `201 Created`
    76→
    77→```json
    78→{
    79→  "id": 1,
    80→  "url": "https://example.com",
    81→  "title": "Example",
    82→  "summary": "A test link",
    83→  "created_at": "2026-02-08T05:24:36+00:00",
    84→  "updated_at": "2026-02-08T05:24:36+00:00"
    85→}
    86→```
    87→
    88→---
    89→
    90→### `GET /links`
    91→
    92→List all links, sorted by newest first.
    93→
    94→**Auth:** `x-api-key` header required
    95→
    96→```bash
    97→curl -H "x-api-key: your-api-key" http://localhost:3000/links
    98→```
    99→
   100→**Response:** `200 OK`
   101→
   102→```json
   103→[
   104→  {
   105→    "id": 2,
   106→    "url": "https://example.com/newer",
   107→    "title": "Newer Article",
   108→    "summary": "...",
   109→    "created_at": "2026-02-09T12:00:00+00:00",
   110→    "updated_at": "2026-02-09T12:00:00+00:00"
   111→  },
   112→  {
   113→    "id": 1,
   114→    "url": "https://example.com/older",
   115→    "title": "Older Article",
   116→    "summary": "...",
   117→    "created_at": "2026-02-08T05:24:36+00:00",
   118→    "updated_at": "2026-02-08T05:24:36+00:00"
   119→  }
   120→]
   121→```
   122→
   123→---
   124→
   125→### `GET /links/:id`
   126→
   127→Get a single link by ID.
   128→
   129→**Auth:** `x-api-key` header required
   130→
   131→```bash
   132→curl -H "x-api-key: your-api-key" http://localhost:3000/links/1
   133→```
   134→
   135→**Response:** `200 OK`
   136→
   137→```json
   138→{
   139→  "id": 1,
   140→  "url": "https://example.com",
   141→  "title": "Example",
   142→  "summary": "A test link",
   143→  "created_at": "2026-02-08T05:24:36+00:00",
   144→  "updated_at": "2026-02-08T05:24:36+00:00"
   145→}
   146→```
   147→
   148→**Error:** `404 Not Found` if the link does not exist.
   149→
   150→---
   151→
   152→### `PATCH /links/:id`
   153→
   154→Update an existing link.
   155→
   156→**Auth:** `x-api-key` header required
   157→
   158→**Request body** (all fields optional):
   159→
   160→```json
   161→{
   162→  "title": "Updated Title",
   163→  "summary": "Updated notes"
   164→}
   165→```
   166→
   167→| Field     | Type   | Required | Description            |
   168→| --------- | ------ | -------- | ---------------------- |
   169→| `url`     | string | no       | Updated URL            |
   170→| `title`   | string | no       | Updated title          |
   171→| `summary` | string | no       | Updated summary/notes  |
   172→
   173→**Example:**
   174→
   175→```bash
   176→curl -X PATCH http://localhost:3000/links/1 \
   177→  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   178→  -H "x-api-key: your-api-key" \
   179→  -d '{"title":"Better Title"}'
   180→```
   181→
   182→**Response:** `200 OK` with the updated link object.
   183→
   184→**Error:** `404 Not Found` if the link does not exist.
   185→
   186→---
   187→
   188→### `DELETE /links/:id`
   189→
   190→Delete a link.
   191→
   192→**Auth:** `x-api-key` header required
   193→
   194→```bash
   195→curl -X DELETE http://localhost:3000/links/1 \
   196→  -H "x-api-key: your-api-key"
   197→```
   198→
   199→**Response:** `204 No Content`
   200→
   201→**Error:** `404 Not Found` if the link does not exist.
   202→
   203→---
   204→
   205→### `GET /feed`
   206→
   207→Public RSS 2.0 feed of all links, newest first.
   208→
   209→**Auth:** None
   210→
   211→```bash
   212→curl http://localhost:3000/feed
   213→```
   214→
   215→**Response:** `200 OK` with `Content-Type: application/rss+xml`
   216→
   217→```xml
   218→<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
   219→<rss version="2.0">
   220→  <channel>
   221→    <title>Linkblog</title>
   222→    <link>https://luther.io/blogroll</link>
   223→    <description>Links worth reading</description>
   224→    <item>
   225→      <title>Interesting Article</title>
   226→      <link>https://example.com/article</link>
   227→      <description>A short note about why this is worth reading.</description>
   228→      <pubDate>Sat, 08 Feb 2026 05:24:36 GMT</pubDate>
   229→      <guid>https://example.com/article</guid>
   230→    </item>
   231→  </channel>
   232→</rss>
   233→```
   234→
   235→---
   236→
   237→## Error Responses
   238→
   239→All errors follow a consistent format:
   240→
   241→```json
   242→{
   243→  "statusCode": 401,
   244→  "message": "Unauthorized"
   245→}
   246→```
   247→
   248→| Status Code | Meaning               |
   249→| ----------- | --------------------- |
   250→| `400`       | Bad Request (invalid body) |
   251→| `401`       | Unauthorized (missing/bad API key) |
   252→| `404`       | Not Found             |
   253→| `500`       | Internal Server Error  |
   254→
   255→---
   256→
   257→## Data Model
   258→
   259→The `links` table in Supabase:
   260→
   261→| Column       | Type          | Description                    |
   262→| ------------ | ------------- | ------------------------------ |
   263→| `id`         | integer (PK)  | Auto-assigned identifier       |
   264→| `url`        | text          | The bookmarked URL             |
   265→| `title`      | text          | Display title                  |
   266→| `summary`    | text          | Notes or brief description     |
   267→| `created_at` | timestamptz   | When the link was saved        |
   268→| `updated_at` | timestamptz   | When the link was last changed |
   269→
   270→---
   271→
   272→Next: [Architecture](architecture)
   273→

1→# For detailed configuration reference documentation, visit:
     2→# https://supabase.com/docs/guides/local-development/cli/config
     3→# A string used to distinguish different Supabase projects on the same host. Defaults to the
     4→# working directory name when running `supabase init`.
     5→project_id = "linkblog"
     6→
     7→[api]
     8→enabled = true
     9→# Port to use for the API URL.
    10→port = 54321
    11→# Schemas to expose in your API. Tables, views and stored procedures in this schema will get API
    12→# endpoints. `public` and `graphql_public` schemas are included by default.
    13→schemas = ["public", "graphql_public"]
    14→# Extra schemas to add to the search_path of every request.
    15→extra_search_path = ["public", "extensions"]
    16→# The maximum number of rows returns from a view, table, or stored procedure. Limits payload size
    17→# for accidental or malicious requests.
    18→max_rows = 1000
    19→
    20→[api.tls]
    21→# Enable HTTPS endpoints locally using a self-signed certificate.
    22→enabled = false
    23→# Paths to self-signed certificate pair.
    24→# cert_path = "../certs/my-cert.pem"
    25→# key_path = "../certs/my-key.pem"
    26→
    27→[db]
    28→# Port to use for the local database URL.
    29→port = 54322
    30→# Port used by db diff command to initialize the shadow database.
    31→shadow_port = 54320
    32→# Maximum amount of time to wait for health check when starting the local database.
    33→health_timeout = "2m"
    34→# The database major version to use. This has to be the same as your remote database's. Run `SHOW
    35→# server_version;` on the remote database to check.
    36→major_version = 17
    37→
    38→[db.pooler]
    39→enabled = false
    40→# Port to use for the local connection pooler.
    41→port = 54329
    42→# Specifies when a server connection can be reused by other clients.
    43→# Configure one of the supported pooler modes: `transaction`, `session`.
    44→pool_mode = "transaction"
    45→# How many server connections to allow per user/database pair.
    46→default_pool_size = 20
    47→# Maximum number of client connections allowed.
    48→max_client_conn = 100
    49→
    50→# [db.vault]
    51→# secret_key = "env(SECRET_VALUE)"
    52→
    53→[db.migrations]
    54→# If disabled, migrations will be skipped during a db push or reset.
    55→enabled = true
    56→# Specifies an ordered list of schema files that describe your database.

    58→schema_paths = []

    65→sql_paths = ["./seed.sql"]

    77→# Uncomment to reject non-secure connections to the database.

    87→

    97→# Email testing server. Emails sent with the local dev setup are not actually sent - rather, they

    99→[inbucket]
   100→enabled = true

   102→port = 54324
   103→# Uncomment to expose additional ports for testing user applications that send emails.
   104→# smtp_port = 54325
   105→# pop3_port = 54326
   106→# admin_email = "admin@email.com"

   152→# The base URL of your website. Used as an allow-list for redirects and for constructing URLs used

   158→jwt_expiry = 3600

   160→# jwt_issuer = ""

   162→# signing_keys_path = "./signing_keys.json"
   163→# If disabled, the refresh token will never expire.
   164→enable_refresh_token_rotation = true

   167→refresh_token_reuse_interval = 10
   168→# Allow/disallow new user signups to your project.

   173→enable_manual_linking = false
   174→# Passwords shorter than this value will be rejected as weak. Minimum 6, recommended 8 or more.

   196→# Configure one of the supported captcha providers: `hcaptcha`, `turnstile`.

   203→# Allow/disallow new user signups via email to your project.

   205→# If enabled, a user will be required to confirm any email change on both the old, and new email

Perfect! Now let me create a comprehensive summary of the codebase exploration:

## Comprehensive Linkblog Codebase Analysis

I've thoroughly explored the linkblog project. Here's a detailed understanding of the structure, patterns, and implementation details:

### 1. **Overall Project Structure**

**NestJS Modules Hierarchy:**
- **AppModule** (root) - imports ConfigModule (global), SupabaseModule, and LinksModule
- **ConfigModule** - global environment variable access
- **SupabaseModule** - @Global() provider for Supabase client
- **LinksModule** - CRUD operations for links

**Directory Layout:**
```
src/
├── main.ts                    # Bootstrap (port from env, defaults to 3000)
├── app.module.ts              # Root module
├── app.controller.ts          # Root route handler (GET / returns "Hello World!")
├── app.service.ts             # Root service
├── supabase/
│   └── supabase.module.ts    # Global Supabase client provider
└── links/
    ├── links.module.ts        # Links feature module
    ├── links.controller.ts    # HTTP endpoints
    ├── links.service.ts       # CRUD business logic
    ├── entities/
    │   └── link.entity.ts    # Empty entity placeholder
    └── dto/
        ├── create-link.dto.ts
        └── update-link.dto.ts
```

### 2. **Data Model**

**Supabase `links` Table:**
- `id` (integer, PK) - auto-assigned
- `url` (text) - the bookmarked URL
- `title` (text) - display title
- `summary` (text) - optional notes/description
- `created_at` (timestamptz, default: now())
- `updated_at` (timestamptz, default: now())

Sample seed data includes 6 test links with realistic URLs and titles.

### 3. **Existing Endpoints Implementation**

**LinksController** (`src/links/links.controller.ts`):
- `POST /links` - Create a link (calls `linksService.create()`)
- `GET /links` - List all links (calls `linksService.findAll()`)
- `GET /links/:id` - Get single link (calls `linksService.findOne(+id)`)
- `PATCH /links/:id` - Update link (calls `linksService.update(+id, dto)`)
- `DELETE /links/:id` - Delete link (calls `linksService.remove(+id)`)

**LinksService** (`src/links/links.service.ts`):

Current implementation status:
- `findAll()` - **FULLY IMPLEMENTED**: Queries Supabase, orders by `created_at` descending, throws `InternalServerErrorException` on error
- `create()`, `findOne()`, `update()`, `remove()` - **STUBS** (placeholder implementations)

Key patterns in `findAll()`:
```typescript
async findAll() {
  const { data, error } = await this.supabase
    .from('links')
    .select('*')
    .order('created_at', { ascending: false });

  if (error) {
    throw new InternalServerErrorException(error.message);
  }
  return data;
}
```

**AppController** (root):
- `GET /` - Returns "Hello World!" (currently used for health check)

### 4. **Feed-Related Code**

Currently there is **no feed implementation** yet. The Postman collection has a "Feed" folder with one request:
- **Test endpoint:** `GET /feed`
- **Expected behavior:** Returns RSS 2.0 XML with Content-Type header `application/rss+xml`
- **Content checks:** Tests verify `<channel>` tag exists in XML response

Expected RSS structure (from API docs):
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<rss version="2.0">
  <channel>
    <title>Linkblog</title>
    <link>https://luther.io/blogroll</link>
    <description>Links worth reading</description>
    <item>
      <title>Article Title</title>
      <link>https://example.com/article</link>
      <description>Summary/notes</description>
      <pubDate>Sat, 08 Feb 2026 05:24:36 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://example.com/article</guid>
    </item>
  </channel>
</rss>
```

### 5. **Implementation Plan Status** (from docs/implementation-plan.md)

**Phase 1-2: ✅ Complete**
- Repository initialized with tooling
- Implementation plan documented
- Supabase project provisioned with `links` table
- NestJS skeleton set up
- SupabaseModule created and integrated

**Phase 3: 🟡 Partial**
- LinksService: `findAll()` done, other CRUD methods are stubs
- LinksController: Routes defined but depend on service implementation
- ApiKeyGuard: Not yet implemented

**Phase 4: ⭕ Not Started**
- FeedModule needs to be created
- FeedController with `GET /feed` endpoint
- RSS 2.0 generation (implementation plan mentions `feed` npm package)

**Phase 5: ⭕ Not Started**
- Dockerfile setup
- `GET /health` endpoint for App Runner

### 6. **Supabase Client Integration**

**SupabaseModule** (`src/supabase/supabase.module.ts`):
- Global module that provides `SUPABASE_CLIENT` injection token
- Uses `ConfigService` to read `SUPABASE_URL` and `SUPABASE_ANON_KEY`
- Disables auth features not needed in backend: `autoRefreshToken: false, persistSession: false`
- Exported for global use

**Injection pattern:**
```typescript
constructor(
  @Inject(SUPABASE_CLIENT) private readonly supabase: SupabaseClient,
) {}
```

**Query patterns used:**
- Chaining: `.from('links').select('*').order('created_at', { ascending: false })`
- Error handling: Always check `{ data, error }` before using data

### 7. **Package.json Dependencies**

**Key production dependencies:**
- `@nestjs/common`, `@nestjs/core`, `@nestjs/platform-express` (v11.1.13)
- `@nestjs/config` (v4.0.3) - for ConfigModule
- `@nestjs/mapped-types` - for PartialType in DTOs
- `@supabase/supabase-js` (v2.95.3) - database client
- `reflect-metadata`, `rxjs` - NestJS fundamentals

**Dev dependencies:**
- Testing: Jest, SuperTest, ts-jest
- Linting: oxlint (v1.43.0), oxfmt (v0.28.0)
- TypeScript (v5.9.3) with strict mode

### 8. **Testing Patterns**

**LinksService tests** (`links.service.spec.ts`):
- Mocks Supabase client with jest.fn() chain mocking
- Tests both success and error scenarios
- Verifies correct parameters passed to Supabase

**LinksController tests** (`links.controller.spec.ts`):
- Basic module setup test (no detailed test cases yet)

**Postman Collection** (`postman/collection.json`):
- Health folder: Basic health check + auth edge cases (no API key, wrong key)
- Links folder: Create link, list links, get one, etc.
- Feed folder: Single RSS feed test
- CRUD Workflow folder: Sequential test workflow with auto-captured `linkId`
- Auto-capture scripts extract `linkId` from responses for downstream requests

### 9. **Key Conventions & Patterns**

**Dependency Injection:**
- All services injected via constructor
- Global modules accessible everywhere
- Provider tokens used for specific instances (e.g., `SUPABASE_CLIENT`)

**Error Handling:**
- Throw NestJS exceptions (`InternalServerErrorException`, `NotFoundException` expected)
- Check Supabase `{ data, error }` before using data
- No error throwing from Supabase client—errors returned in object

**HTTP Methods:**
- `@Post()`, `@Get()`, `@Patch()`, `@Delete()` decorators
- `@Body()`, `@Param()` for input
- Status codes: 201 Created (POST), 200 OK (GET/PATCH), 204 No Content (DELETE)

**Authentication:**
- API key protection via `x-api-key` header
- Guard not yet implemented but planned
- App Runner health check endpoint needs to be public

### 10. **Environment Variables**

**Required:**
- `SUPABASE_URL` - Supabase project URL
- `SUPABASE_ANON_KEY` - Supabase anonymous key
- `API_KEY` - Protects write endpoints

**Optional:**
- `PORT` - Server port (defaults to 3000, set by App Runner in production)

---

## Summary

The project is a well-structured NestJS API with:
- **Complete foundation:** Supabase integration working, basic project structure in place
- **Partial implementation:** Links service partially done (`findAll()` works), controller routes defined
- **Missing pieces:** Feed endpoint not implemented, API key guard not implemented, CRUD methods are stubs
- **Clear patterns:** Dependency injection, error handling, Supabase query chains all established
- **Good testing infrastructure:** Postman collection with auto-capture scripts, Jest setup for unit tests

To implement the `/feed` endpoint, you'll follow the established patterns:
1. Create a new `FeedModule` with `FeedController` and optionally `FeedService`
2. Inject the Supabase client using the `SUPABASE_CLIENT` token
3. Query all links (similar to `LinksService.findAll()`)
4. Convert links to RSS 2.0 XML items
5. Return with `Content-Type: application/rss+xml` header

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/vluther/work/personal/linkblog/.claude/skills/github-issues-first

# GitHub Issues First

## Overview

**No code without an issue.** Every code change must be tracked by a GitHub issue created BEFORE implementation begins. This ensures work is planned, trackable, and reviewable.

## The Iron Rule

```
NO CODE WITHOUT A GITHUB ISSUE FIRST
```

Before writing ANY code - even a one-line fix - create a GitHub issue that describes what you're doing and why.

**Violating the letter of this rule is violating the spirit of this rule.**

## When to Create Issues

**ALWAYS before:**

- New features
- Bug fixes
- Refactoring
- Schema changes
- Configuration changes
- Any code modification

**The ONLY exceptions:**

- Updating documentation-only files (README, CLAUDE.md)
- Adding/modifying comments with zero code changes

## Issue Creation Process

### 1. Before ANY implementation, create the issue

Use the `gh` CLI:

```bash
gh issue create --title "Short imperative description" --body "$(cat <<'EOF'
## What
[What needs to be done - be specific]

## Why
[Why this change is needed]

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Criterion 1
- [ ] Criterion 2
- [ ] Criterion 3

## Notes
[Design decisions, constraints, dependencies on other issues]
EOF
)"
```

### 2. Reference the issue number in your work

- Branch names: `feature/42-add-tagging-system`
- Commits: reference `#42` in commit messages
- PRs: reference `Closes #42` in PR description

### 3. Break large features into multiple issues

If a feature requires multiple steps (scaffolding, schema, API, tests), create separate issues for each. Use labels or a parent issue to group them.

## Quick Reference

| Action         | Command                                        |
| -------------- | ---------------------------------------------- |
| Create issue   | `gh issue create --title "..." --body "..."`   |
| List issues    | `gh issue list`                                |
| View issue     | `gh issue view <number>`                       |
| Close issue    | `gh issue close <number>`                      |
| Add labels     | `gh issue edit <number> --add-label "feature"` |
| Check existing | `gh issue list --search "keyword"`             |

## Red Flags - STOP and Create an Issue

You are about to violate this rule if:

- You're writing code and there's no issue number to reference
- You think "this is too small for an issue"
- You think "I'll create the issue after"
- You feel urgency to "just start coding"
- The user says "let's get this done quickly" and you skip planning
- You're about to scaffold a project without an issue
- You're about to run `npm init` or `nest new` without an issue

**All of these mean: STOP. Create the issue first.**

## Common Rationalizations

| Excuse                             | Reality                                                            |
| ---------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| "It's too small for an issue"      | Small changes still need tracking. Issues take 30 seconds.         |
| "I'll create the issue after"      | You won't. And even if you do, you lost the planning benefit.      |
| "Let's just get this done quickly" | Spending 1 minute on an issue saves 30 minutes of confusion later. |
| "The user didn't ask for an issue" | The project convention is issues-first. Always.                    |
| "I already know what to do"        | Great - then writing the issue will take 15 seconds. Do it.        |
| "It's just a refactor"             | Refactors need tracking too. Create the issue.                     |
| "I'll batch the issues later"      | No. One issue per change, created before the change.               |

## Workflow

```
User asks for change
        |
        v
  Search existing issues
  (gh issue list --search "...")
        |
        v
  Issue exists? ----yes----> Reference it, start work
        |
       no
        |
        v
  Create GitHub issue
  (gh issue create ...)
        |
        v
  Confirm issue # with user
        |
        v
  NOW start implementation
```

## Common Mistakes

1. **Creating vague issues** - "Fix stuff" is not a title. Be specific: "Fix bookmark URL validation to reject malformed URLs"
2. **Skipping acceptance criteria** - If you can't list what "done" looks like, you don't understand the task yet
3. **One mega-issue for everything** - Break work into logical, independently deliverable pieces
4. **Not searching first** - Always check if an issue already exists before creating a duplicate

state:	OPEN
author:	vidluther

--
## What
Create a `GET /feed` endpoint that returns an RSS 2.0 XML feed of all links in reverse chronological order.

## Why
This feed is consumed by luther.io at build time to populate the blogroll at luther.io/blogroll.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `GET /feed` returns valid RSS 2.0 XML
- [ ] Links ordered by `created_at` descending (newest first)
- [ ] Each item includes: title, link (url), description (summary), pubDate (created_at)
- [ ] Feed metadata: title, description, link to the service
- [ ] Endpoint is public (no API key required)
- [ ] Correct `Content-Type: application/rss+xml` header

## Dependencies
- #1 (scaffold), #2 (schema), #3 (Supabase connection)

content.text:
Those test failures are pre-existing (the `.js` extension in imports doesn't resolve in Jest). Not caused by my changes. The build compiles fine since NestJS/TypeScript handles it correctly.

Here's a summary of what was implemented for **issue #9**:

**Files created:**
- `src/feed/feed.module.ts` — imports `LinksModule` to reuse `LinksService`
- `src/feed/feed.service.ts` — calls `linksService.findAll()` and builds RSS 2.0 XML using the `feed` package
- `src/feed/feed.controller.ts` — `GET /feed` with `Content-Type: application/rss+xml` header

**Files modified:**
- `src/links/links.module.ts` — added `exports: [LinksService]` so FeedModule can use it
- `src/app.module.ts` — registered `FeedModule`

**Dependency added:**
- `feed` v5.2.0 — for RSS 2.0 generation

The feed endpoint is public (no API key), returns valid RSS 2.0 XML with links ordered newest-first, and each item includes title, link (url), description (summary), and pubDate (created_at) — matching all the acceptance criteria in issue #9.

content.text: The issue is clear. The project uses `moduleResolution: "nodenext"` which requires `.js` extensions in source imports, but Jest (via ts-jest) can't resolve `.js` extensions to `.ts` files. The fix is to add a `moduleNameMapper` to the Jest config that strips the `.js` extension.

     2→layout: default

     4→---
     5→
     6→# Linkblog Service - Implementation Plan
     7→
     8→## Overview
     9→
    10→A personal bookmarking API built with NestJS + TypeScript + Supabase. Stores articles with notes and publishes them as a public RSS feed for the blogroll at luther.io/blogroll.
    11→
    12→## Architecture
    13→
    14→```
    15→Client (curl/scripts) --> NestJS API --> Supabase (Postgres)
    16→                              |
    17→                              +--> GET /feed (public RSS 2.0)
    18→                              +--> CRUD /links (API key protected)
    19→```
    20→
    21→### Key Decisions
    22→
    23→- **Single-user, no auth system** - write endpoints protected by API key (`x-api-key` header)
    24→- **API-only** - no frontend, interaction via API calls
    25→- **Minimal data model** - url, title, summary, created_at, updated_at
    26→- **RSS 2.0 feed** - public, reverse chronological, consumed by luther.io at build time
    27→- **Deploy** - AWS App Runner via Docker
    28→
    29→### Data Model
    30→
    31→**Table: `links`**
    32→
    33→| Column     | Type        | Constraints   |
    34→| ---------- | ----------- | ------------- |
    35→| id         | integer     | PK            |
    36→| url        | text        |               |
    37→| title      | text        |               |
    38→| summary    | text        |               |
    39→| created_at | timestamptz | default now() |
    40→| updated_at | timestamptz | default now() |
    41→
    42→### Endpoints
    43→
    44→| Method | Path       | Auth    | Description                         |
    45→| ------ | ---------- | ------- | ----------------------------------- |
    46→| POST   | /links     | API key | Create a link                       |
    47→| GET    | /links     | API key | List all links (desc by created_at) |
    48→| GET    | /links/:id | API key | Get a single link                   |
    49→| PATCH  | /links/:id | API key | Update a link                       |
    50→| DELETE | /links/:id | API key | Delete a link (204)                 |
    51→| GET    | /feed      | Public  | RSS 2.0 feed                        |
    52→| GET    | /health    | Public  | Health check for App Runner         |
    53→
    54→## GitHub Issues
    55→
    56→| Issue | Title                                              | Depends On | Status |
    57→| ----- | -------------------------------------------------- | ---------- | ------ |
    58→| #1    | Initialize Repository with Development Tooling     | —          | Closed |
    59→| #2    | Create implementation plan                          | —          | Closed |
    60→| #3    | Provision Supabase project & create `links` table   | —          | Closed |
    61→| #4    | Set up NestJS project skeleton                      | #1         | Closed |
    62→| #5    | Create Supabase client provider                     | #4         | Closed |
    63→| #6    | Implement links service (CRUD via Supabase)         | #5         | Open   |
    64→| #7    | Implement links controller & API-key guard          | #6         | Open   |
    65→| #8    | Implement RSS Feed endpoint (`/feed`)               | #6         | Open   |
    66→
    67→## Implementation Phases
    68→
    69→### Phase 1: Foundation (Issues #1–#4) ✅
    70→
    71→**Goal:** Project scaffolded, database ready.
    72→
    73→- [x] Initialize repo with development tooling (Issue #1)
    74→- [x] Create implementation plan (Issue #2)
    75→- [x] Provision Supabase project & create `links` table with migration and seed data (Issue #3)
    76→- [x] Set up NestJS project skeleton with TypeScript strict mode, oxlint, links module scaffold (Issue #4)
    77→
    78→### Phase 2: Supabase Client (Issue #5) ✅
    79→
    80→**Goal:** NestJS can talk to Supabase.
    81→
    82→- [x] Install `@nestjs/config` and configure `ConfigModule.forRoot({ isGlobal: true })`
    83→- [x] Create `SupabaseModule` (`@Global()`) that provides a configured `@supabase/supabase-js` client
    84→- [x] Client options disable `autoRefreshToken` and `persistSession` (server-side best practice)
    85→- [x] Import `SupabaseModule` in `AppModule`
    86→- [x] Verify connection works with a simple query
    87→
    88→### Phase 3: Core API (Issues #6, #7)
    89→
    90→**Goal:** Full CRUD for links, protected by API key.
    91→
    92→#### Links Service (Issue #6)
    93→
    94→- [x] `findAll()` — returns links ordered by `created_at` descending
    95→- [ ] `findOne(id)` — returns a single link or throws `NotFoundException`
    96→- [ ] `create(dto)` — inserts a link and returns it
    97→- [ ] `update(id, dto)` — updates and returns, throws if missing
    98→- [ ] `remove(id)` — deletes, throws if missing
    99→- [ ] All methods check `{ data, error }` and throw on error
   100→- [ ] Unit tests with mocked Supabase client
   101→
   102→#### Controller & API Key Guard (Issue #7)
   103→
   104→- [ ] `ApiKeyGuard` reads `x-api-key` header, compares to `API_KEY` env var, returns 401 on mismatch
   105→- [ ] `GET /links` and `GET /links/:id` — public
   106→- [ ] `POST /links`, `PATCH /links/:id`, `DELETE /links/:id` — protected
   107→- [ ] DTOs use `class-validator` decorators
   108→- [ ] E2e tests (with and without valid API key)
   109→
   110→### Phase 4: RSS Feed (Issue #8)
   111→
   112→**Goal:** Public RSS feed for luther.io consumption.
   113→
   114→- [ ] Create `FeedModule` + `FeedController`
   115→- [ ] `GET /feed` returns RSS 2.0 XML (`Content-Type: application/rss+xml`)
   116→- [ ] Uses `feed` npm package to build RSS document
   117→- [ ] Each link → `<item>` with `<title>`, `<link>`, `<description>`, `<pubDate>`, `<guid>`
   118→- [ ] Unit/e2e test verifies valid XML output
   119→
   120→### Phase 5: Deployment (no issue yet)
   121→
   122→**Goal:** Dockerized and deployable to AWS App Runner.
   123→
   124→- [ ] Multi-stage Dockerfile (build + production with slim Node base)
   125→- [ ] `.dockerignore` (node_modules, .git, .env, etc.)
   126→- [ ] `GET /health` endpoint for App Runner health checks
   127→- [ ] PORT read from environment (App Runner sets this)
   128→
   129→## Dependency Graph
   130→
   131→```
   132→Phase 1:  #1 (tooling) ──> #4 (skeleton) ──> #5 (supabase client)
   133→          #2 (plan)                                │
   134→          #3 (schema)                              v
   135→                                              #6 (service) ──┬──> #7 (controller + guard)
   136→                                                             └──> #8 (RSS feed)
   137→```
   138→

# Linkblog Service - Implementation Plan

## Overview

A personal bookmarking API built with NestJS + TypeScript + Supabase. Stores articles with notes and publishes them as a public RSS feed for the blogroll at luther.io/blogroll.

## Architecture

```
Client (curl/scripts) --> NestJS API --> Supabase (Postgres)
                              |
                              +--> GET /feed (public RSS 2.0)
                              +--> CRUD /links (API key protected)
```

### Key Decisions

# Linkblog Service - Implementation Plan

## Overview

A personal bookmarking API built with NestJS + TypeScript + Supabase. Stores articles with notes and publishes them as a public RSS feed for the blogroll at luther.io/blogroll.

## Architecture

```
Client (curl/scripts) --> NestJS API --> Supabase (Postgres)
                              |
                              +--> GET /feed (public RSS 2.0)
                              +--> CRUD /links (API key protected)
```

### Key Decisions

- **Single-user, no auth system** - write endpoints protected by API key (`x-api-key` header)
- **API-only** - no frontend, interaction via API calls
- **Minimal data model** - url, title, summary, created_at, updated_at
- **RSS 2.0 feed** - public, reverse chronological, consumed by luther.io at build time
- **Deploy** - AWS App Runner via Docker

### Data Model

**Table: `links`**

| Column     | Type        | Constraints   |
| ---------- | ----------- | ------------- |
| id         | integer     | PK            |
| url        | text        |               |
| title      | text        |               |
| summary    | text        |               |
| created_at | timestamptz | default now() |
| updated_at | timestamptz | default now() |

| Method | Path       | Auth    | Description                         |

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/vluther/.claude/skills/gitbutler

# GitButler CLI Skill

Help users work with GitButler CLI (`but` command) in workspace mode.

## Proactive Agent Workflow

**CRITICAL:** Follow this pattern for EVERY task involving code changes:

1. **Check state** → `but status --json` (always use `--json` for structured output)
2. **Start work** → `but branch new <task-name>` (create stack for this work theme)
3. **Make changes** → Edit files as needed
4. **Commit work** → `but commit <branch> -m "message" --files <id>,<id>` (commit specific files by CLI ID)
5. **Refine** → Use `but absorb` or `but squash` to clean up history

**Commit early, commit often.** Don't hesitate to create commits - GitButler makes editing history trivial. You can always `squash`, `reword`, or `absorb` changes into existing commits later. Small atomic commits are better than large uncommitted changes.

## After Using Write/Edit Tools

When ready to commit:

1. Run `but status --json` to see uncommitted changes and get their CLI IDs
2. Commit the relevant files directly: `but commit <branch> -m "message" --files <id>,<id>`

You can batch multiple file edits before committing - no need to commit after every single change.

## Critical Concept: Workspace Model

**GitButler ≠ Traditional Git**

- **Traditional Git**: One branch at a time, switch with `git checkout`
- **GitButler**: Multiple stacks simultaneously in one workspace, changes assigned to stacks

**This means:**

- ❌ Don't use `git status`, `git commit`, `git checkout`
- ✅ Use `but status`, `but commit`, `but` commands
- ✅ Read-only git commands are fine (`git log`, `git diff`)

## Quick Start

**Installation:**

```bash
curl -sSL https://gitbutler.com/install.sh | sh
but setup                          # Initialize in your repo
but skill install --path <path>    # Install/update skill (agents use --path with known location)
```

**Note for AI agents:**
- When installing or updating this skill programmatically, always use `--path` to specify the exact installation directory. The `--detect` flag requires user interaction if multiple installations exist.
- **Use `--json` flag for all commands** to get structured, parseable output. This is especially important for `but status --json` to reliably parse workspace state.

**Core workflow:**

```bash
but status --json       # Always start here - shows workspace state (JSON for agents)
but branch new feature  # Create new stack for work
# Make changes...
but commit <branch> -m "…" --files <id>,<id>  # Commit specific files by CLI ID
but push <branch>       # Push to remote
```

## Essential Commands

For detailed command syntax and all available options, see [references/reference.md](references/reference.md).

**IMPORTANT for AI agents:** Add `--json` flag to all commands for structured, parseable output.

**Understanding state:**

- `but status --json` - Overview (START HERE, always use --json for agents)
- `but status --json -f` - Overview with full file lists (use when you need to see all changed files)
- `but show <id> --json` - Details about commit/branch
- `but diff <id>` - Show diff

**Flags explanation:**
- `--json` - Output structured JSON instead of human-readable text (always use for agents)
- `-f` - Include detailed file lists in status output (combines with --json: `but status --json -f`)

**Organizing work:**

- `but branch new <name>` - Independent branch
- `but branch new <name> -a <anchor>` - Stacked branch (dependent)
- `but stage <file> <branch>` - Pre-assign file to branch (optional, for organizing before commit)

**Making changes:**

- `but commit <branch> -m "msg" --files <id>,<id>` - Commit specific files or hunks (recommended)
- `but commit <branch> -m "msg" -F <id>,<id>` - Same as above, using short flag
- `but commit <branch> -m "msg"` - Commit ALL uncommitted changes to branch
- `but commit <branch> --only -m "msg"` - Commit only pre-staged changes (cannot combine with --files)
- `but amend <file-id> <commit-id>` - Amend file into specific commit (explicit control)
- `but absorb <file-id>` - Absorb file into auto-detected commit (smart matching)
- `but absorb <branch-id>` - Absorb all changes staged to a branch
- `but absorb` - Absorb ALL uncommitted changes (use with caution)

**Getting IDs for --files:**
- **File IDs**: `but status --json` - commit entire files
- **Hunk IDs**: `but diff --json` - commit individual hunks (for fine-grained control when a file has multiple changes)

**Editing history:**

- `but rub <source> <dest>` - Universal edit (stage/amend/squash/move)
- `but squash <commits>` - Combine commits
- `but reword <id>` - Change commit message/branch name

**Remote operations:**

- `but pull` - Update with upstream
- `but push [branch]` - Push to remote
- `but pr new <branch>` - Push and create pull request (auto-pushes, no need to push first)
- `but pr new <branch> -m "Title..."` - Inline PR message (first line is title, rest is description)
- `but pr new <branch> -F pr_message.txt` - PR message from file (first line is title, rest is description)
- For stacked branches, the custom message (`-m` or `-F`) only applies to the selected branch; dependent branches use defaults

## Key Concepts

For deeper understanding of the workspace model, dependency tracking, and philosophy, see [references/concepts.md](references/concepts.md).

**CLI IDs**: Every object gets a short ID (e.g., `c5` for commit, `bu` for branch). Use these as arguments.

**Parallel vs Stacked branches**:

- Parallel: Independent work that doesn't depend on each other
- Stacked: Dependent work where one feature builds on another

**The `but rub` primitive**: Core operation that does different things based on what you combine:

- File + Branch → Stage
- File + Commit → Amend
- Commit + Commit → Squash
- Commit + Branch → Move

## Workflow Examples

For complete step-by-step workflows and real-world scenarios, see [references/examples.md](references/examples.md).

**Starting independent work:**

```bash
but status --json
but branch new api-endpoint
but branch new ui-update
# Make changes, then commit specific files to appropriate branches
but status --json  # Get file CLI IDs
but commit api-endpoint -m "Add endpoint" --files <api-file-id>
but commit ui-update -m "Update UI" --files <ui-file-id>
```

**Committing specific hunks (fine-grained control):**

```bash
but diff --json             # See hunk IDs when a file has multiple changes
but commit <branch> -m "Fix first issue" --files <hunk-id-1>
but commit <branch> -m "Fix second issue" --files <hunk-id-2>
```

**Cleaning up commits:**

```bash
but absorb              # Auto-amend changes
but status --json       # Verify absorb result
but squash <branch>     # Squash all commits in branch
```

**Resolving conflicts:**

```bash
but resolve <commit>    # Enter resolution mode
# Fix conflicts in editor
but resolve finish      # Complete resolution
```

## Guidelines

1. Always start with `but status --json` to understand current state (agents should always use `--json`)
2. Create a new stack for each independent work theme
3. Use `--files` to commit specific files directly - no need to stage first
4. **Commit early and often** - don't wait for perfection. Unlike traditional git, GitButler makes editing history trivial with `absorb`, `squash`, and `reword`. It's better to have small, atomic commits that you refine later than to accumulate large uncommitted changes.
5. **Use `--json` flag for ALL commands** when running as an agent - this provides structured, parseable output instead of human-readable text
6. Use `--dry-run` flags (push, absorb) when unsure
7. Run `but pull` regularly to stay updated with upstream
8. When updating this skill, use `but skill install --path <known-path>` to avoid prompts

Commit changes to a stack.

The `but commit` command allows you to create a new commit
on a specified branch (stack) with the current uncommitted changes.

If there is only one branch applied, it will commit to that branch by default.

If there are multiple branches applied, you must specify which branch to
commit to, or if in interactive mode, you will be prompted to select one.

By default, all uncommitted changes and all changes already staged to that
branch will be included in the commit. If you only want to commit the changes
that are already staged to that branch, you can use the `--only` flag.

It will not commit changes staged to other branches.

Use `but commit empty --before <target>` or `but commit empty --after <target>`
to insert a blank commit. This is useful for creating a placeholder
commit that you can amend changes into later using `but mark`, `but rub` or `but absorb`.

Usage: but commit [OPTIONS] [BRANCH] [COMMAND]

Commands:
  empty  Insert a blank commit before or after the specified commit.

Arguments:
  [BRANCH]
          Branch CLI ID or name to derive the stack to commit to

Options:
